Award.AwardTitle: Support for Students, Post-Docs, and Community College Faculty to Attend 2015 ASME Applied Mechanics and Materials Conference (McMat2015), Seattle, Washington; June 29-July 1, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ASME Applied Mechanics and Materials (McMat) meeting is a quadrennial conference jointly established by the divisions of Applied Mechanics and of Materials of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME). This meeting covers all aspect of mechanics and materials, from experiment, computation to theory. It provides a unique platform for researchers from industry, academia and national labs to come together to present, share and identify the most important developments, trends and innovations in the field. The upcoming McMat 2015 conference, to be held in Seattle, Washington, June 29-July 2, 2015, places special emphasis on advancing the knowledge in the emerging areas of energy, health, soft electronics, advanced manufacturing, and mechanics and materials education. This award will provide partial travel support for beginning researchers including graduate students, postdocs as well as community college faculty members to attend the conference. Special effort will be made to identify and support women and under-represented minority members as they are currently under represented in the mechanics and materials field.

The McMat 2015 is one of the most well attended conference in the mechanics and materials field expecting over 400 participants from over 30 countries. This travel award will foster a greater and more diverse conference participation of US young scholars. It provides a unique opportunity to research active graduate students and postdoc researchers, and community college instructors in mechanics education, to learn about the most recent and important developments and innovations, and to interact with the researchers who are actually working on the forefront of these areas. In addition, the award will promote the participation and recognition of women and underrepresented minorities in the mechanics and materials field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The original goal of this travel grant is to provide partial travel support for beginning researchers including graduate students, postdocs as well as community college faculty members to attend the 2015 ASME Applied Mechanics and Materials Conference (McMat2015) held from June 29-July 1, 2015 in Seattle, WA. Special effort will be made to identify and support women and under-represented minority members as they are currently under represented in the mechanics and materials field.

The outcomes:

The McMat2015 conference was a 3-day conference featured by over 440 presentations in 25 symposia including 4 plenary talks, 27 keynotes and technical presentations by leading researchers in academia, industry and government national labs. With the generous support of this NSF travel grant:

1)    24 researchers were provided partial support to attend the conference, including nineteen PhD students, four post-doctoral researchers and one community college faculty members, among whom there were three female PhD students. The awardees were the best of best selected rigorously by the travel award committee.

2)    A successful poster session was held during the second day of the conference which attracted hundreds conference attendees. It became a hub for the researchers to assemble, talk and share ideas and opinions on the related research.

Many of the researchers supported by this travel grant gave excellent oral and poster presentations during the conference which provided a platform for the conference attendees to learn about their current research. In addition, these beginning researchers got the rare opportunity to attend all the general and technical sessions during the conference and listen to the many talks given by the well-established researchers in the field.

 

Broader Impact

 

The ASME Applied Mechanics and Materials Conference (McMat) is one of the most well attended conferences in the mechanics and materials field including researchers from computation, modeling and experimental fields. This travel award fostered a greater and more diverse conference participation of US young scholars.  It provided a unique opportunity to the research active graduate students and postdoc researchers, as well as community college instructors in mechanics education, to learn about the most recent developments and innovations, and to interact with the researchers who are actually working on the forefront of these areas.
